utterances: `He's like a young tenor about to sing in Parma'--Parma's Toscanini's hometown, where opera is like football.
Yeah.
Thumbs up; thumbs down.
It's a terrifying town for young tenors, and Caruso was like one of them.
Yeah.
Even when he was the greatest name in the world.
Yeah.
`And one day this guy Caruso's crazy,' she says.
`He's a good-hearted guy, but one day he calls me up, ""I'm in jail in Chicago."" He's in jail.
How come?
The lady was sitting next to me on the bench near the zoo and I pinch her, you know."" You pinched her fanny?
Yeah, I pinched her fanny, her fanny."" You crazy nut.
She's going to bail him out and the cops are all in awe.
His name was the most famous in the world.
`Oh, my God.
She said, `Never mind your ""Oh, my God."" If he does that again, pinches a woman's fanny, put him in forever.
But she's in the book...
Yeah.
...and she describes herself an overage, overweight singer.
So I'd go from the Caruso records, say, to Louis Armstrong's ""West End Blues.
Ooh, yeah.
That's my favorite.
And that's when Earl Hines plays a certain kind of piano rhythm that's revolutionary.
And then I go from there--I might go to Woody Guthrie singing ""Tom Joad"" who...
And was it just the way it hit you, what you wanted to play at that moment?
Was that what it was?
You bet.
It was just what I felt like at that moment, what I felt like.
And if I felt like it, maybe other people do.
And if they don't, maybe they will.
But the big thing is never to play down to people but to play up to what the possibilities are.
I think I've always felt that.
I don't mean to be romantic about it, but--see, a wonderful case in point.
There was a marvelous book called ""Akenfield"" by a British writer, Ronald Blythe.
It's about a village--part of the Village Series.
My book was one of them, ""Division Street: America."" And it's about a village near London and this is a working man.
He's highly intelligent, but he feels that classical music of Brahms, of Mahler, of Schubert is not for him.
And so the people he sees opening night at the opera in the tabloids, tiaras and furs and top hat, maybe it's for them.
But one day, to get in out of the rain, and it may have been in Manchester, he finds himself in a symphony hall.
And he opens the door slightly and he hears some music and it's Mozart.
And as he listens, he listens and it suddenly hits him: He loves this music.
He does understand it.
He is good enough for Mozart.

So in a sense, what I'm really saying is, if people hear good things often enough--whether it be jazz or blues or spirituals or folk music or classical or Andres Segovia playing the guitar--they'll like it.
You know, you mentioned a little short time ago that you might play Louis Armstrong.
And one of the interviews in this book is with Louis Armstrong, and we have a little clip of tape from that interview.
We're going to play that tape now.
(Soundbite of 1962 interview)
We copied it from them, that beat, tom-toms and drumbeats and all that.
I realized when I went down there that it was copied from them.
So the rhythms...
Yeah.
...the complicated rhythms and African in origin...
I think so, yeah.
...when slaves came here originally brought the...
Came from the Africans.
...music with them.
They still got it.
So when you--so when you went back then, it was almost as though a circle was completed.
Music came there and you were bringing it back.
Right.
Brought way back through generations.
You know, when I was a kid ...(unintelligible) in New Orleans, I could see so many things that was brought from Africa all over the world.
And that was Louis Armstrong in 1962, and he was telling you about his discovery, his understanding, that jazz music, the African roots of the music he played.
That's the first time he visited West Africa and where he felt the music he played as a kid in New Orleans came from.
You see, the thing about that interview--pardon me--that saddened me, he was so tired.
He didn't have to submit to that interview.
I don't know why he did because he was so tired.
He was keeping faith with his agent.
He was playing at a place that didn't care about jazz.
He's established the world over and yet he was playing that night, tired.
His upper lip had a blister the size of a dime, that's from blowing on the trumpet, the umbasheur(ph).
Mm-hmm.
Yesterday, it was a glitch in the system that disseminates prices that shut the NASDAQ down.
And that glitch was caused by a bad connection between big market participants.
W.
GREENE: Even though going through this, Pansy and I are still here.
We're together.
We are a couple.
And I remembered that and I said to him--I remember saying, `Look, we can postpone this.
`No, no. Let's do it.
And that grin--we always associate the grin, that grin was hiding something deep.
There was a hurt there.
Many times, he speaks of that in an oblique sort of way, but it's there throughout, you see.
And then it opened with his first wife, Lil Hardin Armstrong.
And she's wonderful.
She had a joy of life and she taught Louis respect for himself when he came to Chicago to join his mentor, King Oliver, whom he worshipped...
Mm-hmm.
...who was a good man, but she, Lil, was telling Louis, `You respect yourself first.'
And in any event, we have all sorts of people in the book that you wouldn't expect to be are in it.
And it doesn't matter what the form is--Andres Segovia was mentioned, the man who established the classical guitar as...
Yeah.
...a serious musical instrument.
Until he came along, it was there, but there was hardly any repertoire.
And most of the repertoire are his transcriptions of Bach.

And here you've got this 85-year-old guy, not an electrified instrument, acoustic instrument, a delicate one, the classical guitar, and he's got one piece of prop, a footstool and he is holding 5,000 people at Ann Arbor.
And they're listening, they're leaning forward, hearing every note.
And he says, `Some people bawled me out once because I played so softly they had to lean over to listen.
You know what I did the next time?
I played even more softly.
You know why?
So they would listen more.
And he describes this as then you realize that listening is a key.
Yeah.
But the different ways of listening, different instruments.
You can listen to a piano and lean back, but you can't do that with a guitar.
But he describes the guitar as his lover, his paramour, and he kids about it.
But--I'm sorry, you were going to ask me something.
We're going to take a short break right now.
Sure.
And we're going to continue our discussion with you when we come back.
Studs Terkel is my guest today.
This is TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
I'm Lynn Neary.
(Soundbite of ""West End Blues"")
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Lynn Neary in Washington, sitting in for Neal Conan.
And I'm joined in the studio this hour by Studs Terkel.
He's worked as an activist, a civil servant, a labor organizer, a radio deejay, a television actor.
But today, we're talking about his famous interviews with musicians.
If you'd like to reminisce about a favorite Studs Terkel moment or ask what Janis Joplin was really like, you're invited to join the discussion.

And there was one other one I wanted to play right now, but you seem to want to say something right here.
You got a...
